All in all, Poco is a must-play for fans of whimsical, point-and-click adventures. I‚Äôd happily play a whole series of games like this!

Poco is a cute, if bizarre, hand-drawn point & click puzzle game, in a similar vein as games from the Rusty Lake Series or by Madison Karrh.

In this game, you play as the titular character who is trying to return to the circus after being kicked out. To solve your dilemma, you must engage with some peculiar characters and be innovative in the use of the materials you come across as you explore.

The game features absolutely beautiful art and a high-key bop of a soundtrack. I wasn't expecting the latter based on the trailer/screenshots, but was solidly impressed by it.

The only things I take issue with is that some of the solutions are a bit obscure. The game has a hint system, but I avoided using it, so maybe that would have solved my concern, but I also don't like feeling like I need to use hints to progress. For a free game of this quality, it's difficult to complain about the length, but this felt like it could have easily been 2-3x the length and been stronger for it. Either way, the devs showed they can make games of interest to me, and it speaks to its favor that I wanted more of it.

A delightfully written point and click adventure about a clown who seeks to rejoin the flying circus vessel he was ignominiously ejected from, and who meets along the way a series of animals (insects, worms, etc) and strange homonculi whom he must (naturally... ....) assist in a variety of quests.

Typical point and click stuff in many regards, but the art style/graphics are wonderful, there are no galaxy brain solutions required (you and your noggin will probably do just fine!), and with one notable exception the gameplay is straight forward and immensely enjoyable.  The only fly in the ointment is the music mini-game where you must (ala guitar hero etc etc) type/click your action button at the same time as musical notes (well, the equivalent thereof) are falling down the screen in rather speedy fashion.  You will probably have to do this puzzle [b]several[/b] times to get the patterns memorized so you can commit them to muscle memory....don't do what I did and have a couple of adult beverages prior to playing.....your reflexes need to be [b]on point![/b]

Other than that one lamentable interruption to the enjoyment level of the game, I can say that the other 95% of Poco is a delight to play through, and even includes a few dark/twisted nods to other games by the same devs (e.g. Multi-Medium).

Recommended!

An excellent, short yet sweet indie game that flew over my radar until someone pointed it out to me. After having played it and beating it, I have to say, it did not disappoint.

As the store page states, Poco is an exploration and point & click type of game. Poco is the titular character: a 2-inch tall clown that was banished from the mysterious "Circus" and forced to live among the denizens of the Below World. In this other world, you will encounter the characters you'll interact with, the so-called homunculi, which represent the five senses of the human body--something I didn't know about until reading the store page in its entirety!

As for gameplay, as stated before, it's primarily an exploration and point & click type of game. You move Poco around by clicking on areas within the screen and can interact with objects and characters with your cursor. Using this point & click system, you can explore nooks and crannies of the Below World and find secrets hidden within. As for the mainstay of the game, you're tasked with solving basic puzzles and running errands for the homunculi in order to progress through the game. It's a simple game that requires very little thinking, respectfully to the developers, but it's relaxing and easygoing and won't make you stressful in trying to figure out how to get to the next part of the game.

The environments and artwork you encounter in the Below World are also gorgeous to look at. It's a mix between 2D and 3D and the animations are adorably done to the delight of the player. The game also boasts its own soundtrack, which was a joy to listen to. You can also purchase it as a DLC for $0.99 as for the writing of this review.

The one thing that shocked me about this entire game was that it's free. While the game can be completed within 2 hours or even less, depending on whether or not you're actively looking for secrets and how fast you're playing the game, the amount of effort put into this all of this made me think that there should be a price tag added to this. There is, however, a donation page from the game's main menu, and I am considering donating some amount to the developers as I believe they've certainly earned it.

As for anything else I can go on about, there is, from what I've seen, a "hidden" story behind all the happenings of how this world came to be. It can mainly be found through secrets acquired in the game, but since the game is only about 2 hours long, I really wouldn't look into and over-analyze anything. Even so, I immensely enjoyed every moment of exploring this game.

If there are any negative things I have to say, it's just going to be whether or not you enjoy these "old school" type of point & click games. It's absolutely not as arduous and cryptic as those old games from the 1990's and early 2000's, but it certainly has that feel to it. However, again, I immensely enjoyed every moment of this experience and I hope you do too, even if click & point games aren't really your thing. Give it a try!

I really do hope there is a sequel or at least continuation to this game's world, and if there is, I also hope the developers actually put a price tag to it because they've certainly earned the compensation. With all that being said, I'm grateful that this was free to download and play, and I hope to see more from Whalefall in the future.

I usually say that I can't play point-and-clicks. It's not just that I don't like them, I just don't have the drive to "solve" esoteric "puzzles". The games lose my attention.

This game is simple and short, and that's why it has in a few minutes become one of my favorites. The puzzles feel natural, each screen piques curiosity and each little thing you find, be it an item or an unsolved puzzle, is either obvious in what it requires, or it sparks that curiosity that begs you to explore more.
This is how puzzle adventures should be done. This game knows how to lead and knows how to pace itself out, make itself varied enough not to bore.

None of that would really matter if it was a flawed, hard to understand game. It wouldn't be super enjoyable, but the good game design is second to how charming this game is.
All throughout it stays a heart-warming, sincere, and adorable story. In its core is a simple and effective tale for all ages that anyone with half a heart will find meaningful.
But what makes it truly shine is that it doesn't shy away from negativity. Sometimes it is in the few story beats that are simply sad, or how each character is dealing with some flaw, or the odd gruesome joke. 
The thing that is a constant is the same thing that makes it so gorgeous and wonderous: the bizarre, often dark world made up of unsettling creatures and rotting garbage. In a few glimpses we even get see the extents of unimaginable powers that reside in the world. As wholesome as most of the characters are, it is always apparent that this world can be just as cruel as it is goofy or heart-warming.
But the game doesn't dwell on it. The darkness is a background noise that doesn't encroach on the story that celebrates friendship and kindness. It's in the rejection of the cruelty that the game wants to find meaning.

A sweet and short point and click adventure with copious amounts of charm, and it's free to boot. Do play this one, it's super worth your time. 

It doesn't hurt that it's a fairly straightforward game, being on the "definitely will have to screw around a bit" field but without ever really veering into moon logic at all, and the game has a hint system that is incredibly elegant, so it'll give you a push in the right direction without ever telling you verbatim what you have to do. 

It's also just visually and musically beautiful, as well, with a delightfully charming style that blends 3D models over hand-painted, painstakingly detailed backgrounds, all the while having very visually distinct characters. 

The story is not something I'd call ground-breaking but it's got a bit of a fairy tale/fable feel to it that really helps sell the whole thing, in my mind. It's very pleasant and sweet, and it did move my otherwise dead heart a little. 

All in all, a truly fantastic game. Hard to believe it's free; don't pass it up, folks.
